newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Senate passes go-it-alone chemical arms bill.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Senate passes go-it-alone chemical arms bill.

text.p: The Senate on Thursday approved a bill under which the United States would take a unilateral approach to fighting the spread of chemical weapons.
The near party-line vote of 53-44 came shortly after the Senate agreed on plans to debate next week a global treaty outlawing chemical weapons.
The Clinton administration strongly opposed the bill calling it "a deficient and unworkable alternative" to the treaty, known as the Chemical Weapons Convention.
The bill would ban chemical and biological weapons within the United States and require U.S. sanctions against other countries using them.
It also would require continuing enhancements of U.S. defences against chemical and biological weapons.
Democrats complained the bill had been brought to the Senate without prior consideration, unlike the 1993 chemical weapons treaty which has been ratified by more than 70 countries.
